poem:
I am the steel serpent on Route 110,  
my engine’s pulse a low hum that coils  
around the curbside benches.  

Morning air drips of burnt coffee and rubber,  
and I inhale the city’s scattered prayers—  
cottonwoods shaking dust like confetti  
over cracked sidewalks.  

At every stop, I purr—  
a rolling lullaby that spills through open doors,  
inviting tired souls to climb aboard  
my ribbed spine of welded steel.  
Their boots scuff the floor,  
their breath fogs the windows,  
and I cradle them in the rocking cradle  
of my restless heart.  

When a line of geese shuffles across the asphalt,  
I barrel onward with a calculated shrug—  
their honks dissolve beneath my tire’s roar.  
No pause for their feathered parade:  
I have rhythms to keep,  
an unsettled map of destinies to trace  
through concrete canyons and neon veins.  

I taste the autumn haze on my grille—  
fading sunlight battered by smoky chimneys,  
the tang of salt from parking garages.  
Brake lights flare like distant stars  
as I weave between shadows and streetlamps,  
each intersection a chance to rewrite the map.  

Inside, overheard whispers rise and fall—  
a mother’s lullaby, a teenager’s secret,  
a construction worker’s grimace at the heat.  
I carry them all,  
a thundercloud of stories draped in vinyl seats.  

Night descends in flickers of amber and chrome.  
I hum still, a restless ghost  
chasing fugitives of time.  
On Route 110, I am the city’s unruly pulse,  
its humming vessel of motion—  
undaunted by geese, unbroken by distance,  
guided by the wild compass of steel and spark.
